newsitem.title: UK: Clean tanker rates seen struggling next week.
newsitem.headline: Clean tanker rates seen struggling next week.

text.p: Clean tanker rates struggled to maintain momentum in the face of public holidays and may lose further momentum next week, brokers said on Friday.
The Middle East market was torpid with little enquiry and few fixtures, with 28,000-30,000 tonne gas oil cargoes to India sagging at around W175 and 30,000 tonne stems to Japan at W180.
Sparse activity in the 30,000 tonne Middle East market meant that owners continued to send tonnage in ballast to the Mediterranean, brokers said.
"With a surplus of prompt tonnage in the Middle East Gulf area and enquiry so low, freight rates are not expected to rise in the coming weeks," said brokers E.A. Gibson in their weekly tanker report.
In the Med, enquiry exceeded suitable available tonnage towards the end of the week, with 27,500 tonne naphtha stems rising to around W235 and gas oil at W190/200.

Gas oil was steady at W205 in the inter-U.K./cont sector on reasonable enquiry, while there was good interest in shipping unleaded gasoline to the U.S. Typical trans-Atlantic rates were W165 for 60,000 tonnes and W210/220 on 33,000 tonnes, Gibson said.
In the Caribbean, 30,000 tonne rates have fallen by about 10 points but there may be sufficient demand to prevent a collapse, brokers said.
